documentation.short: MainC is the system interface the TinyOS boot sequence.

Implementation of TEP 112 (Microcontroller Power Management) for the Atmega128.
TransformCounterC decreases precision and/or widens an Counter.
RealMain implements the TinyOS boot sequence, as documented in TEP 107.
The TinyOS scheduler.
The virtualized millisecond timer abstraction.
TransformAlarmC decreases precision and/or widens an Alarm.
AlarmToTimerC converts a 32-bit Alarm to a Timer.
VirtualizeTimerC uses a single Timer to create up to 255 virtual timers.
The virtualized millisecond timer abstraction.
The virtualized millisecond timer abstraction.

documentation.short: Generic pin access for pins mapped into I/O space (for which the sbi, cbi instructions give atomic updates).
TransformCounterC decreases precision and/or widens an Counter.
The virtualized millisecond timer abstraction.
TransformAlarmC decreases precision and/or widens an Alarm.
AlarmToTimerC converts a 32-bit Alarm to a Timer.
VirtualizeTimerC uses a single Timer to create up to 255 virtual timers.
Initialize this component.
Interface that notifies components when TinyOS has booted (initialized all of its components), as discussed in TEP 107.
Signaled when the system has booted successfully.
This interface provides functions to compute ATmega128 configuration values that are clock-rate dependent.
documentation.long:
This interface provides functions to compute ATmega128 configuration values that are clock-rate dependent. These include:
  • the ADC prescaler value necessary for full precision
  • values for the UBRR registers to achieve a specific baud rate
  • any adjustment necessary to values passed to some platform-provided AlarmMicroXXC components to get more accurate timing
  • the number of cycles per 1/32768s (a typical implementation of this interface will measure this value at boot time and use it to compute the values above)
@author David Gay

documentation.short: Return the value to use for the baudrate register to achieve a particular baud rate.
documentation.long: Return the value to use for the baudrate register to achieve a particular baud rate. Assumes U2X=1 (the USART is being run at double speed).

documentation.short: Return CPU cycles per 1/32768s.
documentation.long: Return CPU cycles per 1/32768s. @return CPU cycles.

documentation.short: Convert n microseconds into a value suitable for use with AlarmMicro32C Alarms.
Convert values used by AlarmMicro32C Alarms into actual microseconds.
Return the smallest ADC prescaler value which guaranteers full ADC precision.

documentation.long: @author Jonathan Hui <jhui@archedrock.com> @version $Revision: 1.5 $ $Date: 2008-06-04 03:00:35 $

documentation.short: Send a single uart byte.
Receive a single uart byte.

documentation.long: @author Jonathan Hui <jhui@archedrock.com> @version $Revision: 1.5 $ $Date: 2008-06-04 03:00:35 $

documentation.short: Begin transmission of a UART stream.
Signals the receipt of a byte.
documentation.long:
Signals the receipt of a byte.
@param byte The byte received.

documentation.short: Begin reception of a UART stream.
Enable the receive byte interrupt.
Signal completion of receiving a stream.
Disable the receive byte interrupt.
documentation.long:
Disable the receive byte interrupt.
@return SUCCESS if interrupt was disabled, FAIL otherwise.

documentation.short: Signal completion of sending a stream.

Please refer to TEP 115 for more information about this interface and its intended use.

This interface is used to switch between the on and off power states of the component providing it.
documentation.long:
Please refer to TEP 115 for more information about this interface and its intended use.

This interface is used to switch between the on and off power states of the component providing it. A call to the start() command is a request to switch a component into the on state, and a call to the stop() is a request to switch a component into the off state. @author Joe Polastre @author Kevin Klues (klueska@cs.wustl.edu)

documentation.short: Start this component and all of its subcomponents.
documentation.long:
Start this component and all of its subcomponents. @return SUCCESS if the component was either already on or was successfully turned on
FAIL otherwise

documentation.short: Stop the component and any pertinent subcomponents (not all subcomponents may be turned off due to wakeup timers, etc.).
documentation.long:
Stop the component and any pertinent subcomponents (not all subcomponents may be turned off due to wakeup timers, etc.). @return SUCCESS if the component was either already off or was successfully turned off
FAIL otherwise

documentation.short: Post this task to the TinyOS scheduler.
documentation.long:
Post this task to the TinyOS scheduler. At some later time, depending on the scheduling policy, the scheduler will signal the <tt>run()</tt> event.
@return SUCCESS if task was successfuly posted; the semantics of a non-SUCCESS return value depend on the implementation of this interface (the class of task).

documentation.short: Event from the scheduler to run this task.
documentation.long: Event from the scheduler to run this task. Following the TinyOS concurrency model, the codes invoked from <tt>run()</tt> signals execute atomically with respect to one another, but can be preempted by async commands/events.

documentation.short: A Counter counts time in some units and in some width, signaling overflow.
documentation.long:
A Counter counts time in some units and in some width, signaling overflow.

A Counter is parameterised by its "precision" (milliseconds, microseconds, etc), identified by a type. This prevents, e.g., unintentionally mixing components expecting milliseconds with those expecting microseconds as those interfaces have a different type.

A Counter's second parameter is its "width", i.e., the number of bits used to represent time values. Width is indicated by including the appropriate size integer type as a Counter parameter.

See TEP102 for more details. @param precision_tag A type indicating the precision of this Counter. @param size_type An integer type representing time values for this Counter. @author Cory Sharp

documentation.short: Return counter value.
Cancel a pending overflow interrupt.
documentation.long: Cancel a pending overflow interrupt.

documentation.short: Return TRUE if an overflow event will occur after the outermost atomic block is exits.
Signals that the current time has overflowed.
documentation.long: Signals that the current time has overflowed. That is, the current time has wrapped around from its maximum value to zero.

documentation.short: Constants for manipulating LEDs.
Turn off LED 0.
documentation.long: Turn off LED 0. The color of this LED depends on the platform.

documentation.short: Toggle LED 0; if it was off, turn it on, if was on, turn it off.
documentation.long: Toggle LED 0; if it was off, turn it on, if was on, turn it off. The color of this LED depends on the platform.

documentation.short: Turn on LED 1.
documentation.long: Turn on LED 1. The color of this LED depends on the platform.

documentation.short: Toggle LED 1; if it was off, turn it on, if was on, turn it off.
documentation.long: Toggle LED 1; if it was off, turn it on, if was on, turn it off. The color of this LED depends on the platform.

documentation.short: Toggle LED 2; if it was off, turn it on, if was on, turn it off.
documentation.long: Toggle LED 2; if it was off, turn it on, if was on, turn it off. The color of this LED depends on the platform.

documentation.short: Get the current LED settings as a bitmask.
documentation.long:
Get the current LED settings as a bitmask. Each bit corresponds to whether an LED is on; bit 0 is LED 0, bit 1 is LED 1, etc. You can also use the enums LEDS_LED0, LEDS_LED1. For example, this expression will determine whether LED 2 is on: 
 (call Leds.get() & LEDS_LED2)
This command supports up to 8 LEDs; if a platform has fewer, then those LEDs should always be off (their bit is zero). Also see set(). @return a bitmask describing which LEDs are on and which are off

documentation.short: Turn off LED 1.
documentation.long: Turn off LED 1. The color of this LED depends on the platform.

documentation.short: Set the current LED configuration using a bitmask.
documentation.long:
Set the current LED configuration using a bitmask. Each bit corresponds to whether an LED is on; bit 0 is LED 0, bit 1 is LED 1, etc. You can also use the enums LEDS_LED0, LEDS_LED1. For example, this statement will configure the LEDs so LED 0 and LED 2 are on: 
 call Leds.set(LEDS_LED0 | LEDS_LED2);
This statement will turn LED 1 on if it was not already: 
call Leds.set(call Leds.get() | LEDS_LED1);
@param val a bitmask describing the on/off settings of the LEDs

documentation.short: Turn on LED 0.
documentation.long: Turn on LED 0. The color of this LED depends on the platform.

documentation.short: Turn on LED 2.
documentation.long: Turn on LED 2. The color of this LED depends on the platform.

documentation.short: Turn off LED 2.
documentation.long: Turn off LED 2. The color of this LED depends on the platform.

documentation.short: Interface to allow high-level components to set a lower bound for a microcontroller's low power state.
Called when computing the low power state, in order to allow a high-level component to institute a lower bound.
documentation.long:
Called when computing the low power state, in order to allow a high-level component to institute a lower bound. Because this command originates deep within the basic TinyOS scheduling mechanisms, it should be used very sparingly. Refer to TEP 112 for details.
@return the lowest power state the system can enter to meet the requirements of this component
@author Joe Polastre

documentation.short: Interface to instruct the MCU to enter a low power state.
Called by the scheduler to put the MCU to sleep.
documentation.long: Called by the scheduler to put the MCU to sleep. *

documentation.short: Interface to instruct TinyOS that the low-power state of the MCU may have changed.
Called by any component to tell TinyOS that the MCU low power state may have changed.
documentation.long: Called by any component to tell TinyOS that the MCU low power state may have changed. Generally, this should be called whenever a peripheral/timer is started/stopped.

documentation.short: The interface to a TinyOS task scheduler.
Initialize the scheduler.
documentation.long: Initialize the scheduler.

documentation.short: Enter an infinite task-running loop.
documentation.long: Enter an infinite task-running loop. Put the MCU into a low power state when the processor is idle (task queue empty, waiting for interrupts). This call never returns.

documentation.short: Run the next task if one is waiting, otherwise return immediately.
A Timer is TinyOS's general purpose timing interface.
documentation.long:
A Timer is TinyOS's general purpose timing interface. For more precise timing, you may wish to use a (platform-specific) component offering an Alarm interface.

A Timer is parameterised by its "precision" (milliseconds, microseconds, etc), identified by a type. This prevents, e.g., unintentionally mixing components expecting milliseconds with those expecting microseconds as those interfaces have a different type.

See TEP102 for more details. @param precision_tag A type indicating the precision of this Alarm. @author Cory Sharp

documentation.short: Return the current time.
documentation.long: Return the current time. @return Current time.

documentation.short: Signaled when the timer expires (one-shot) or repeats (periodic).
documentation.long: Signaled when the timer expires (one-shot) or repeats (periodic).

documentation.short: Set a periodic timer to repeat every dt time units.
documentation.long:
Set a periodic timer to repeat every dt time units. Replaces any current timer settings. The fired will be signaled every dt units (first event at t0+dt units). Periodic timers set in the past will get a bunch of events in succession, until the timer "catches up".

Because the current time may wrap around, it is possible to use values of t0 greater than the getNow's result. These values represent times in the past, i.e., the time at which getNow() would last of returned that value. @param t0 Base time for timer. @param dt Time until the timer fires.

documentation.short: Check if this is a one-shot timer.
documentation.long: Check if this is a one-shot timer. @return TRUE for one-shot timers, FALSE for periodic timers.

documentation.short: Return the delay or period for the previously started timer.
Return the time anchor for the previously started timer or the time of the previous event for periodic timers.
documentation.long: Return the time anchor for the previously started timer or the time of the previous event for periodic timers. The next fired event will occur at gett0() + getdt(). @return Timer's base time.

documentation.short: Check if timer is running.
Set a periodic timer to repeat every dt time units.
documentation.long: Set a periodic timer to repeat every dt time units. Replaces any current timer settings. Equivalent to startPeriodicAt(getNow(), dt). The fired will be signaled every dt units (first event in dt units). @param dt Time until the timer fires.

documentation.short: Set a single-short timer to time t0+dt.
documentation.long:
Set a single-short timer to time t0+dt. Replaces any current timer settings. The fired will be signaled when the timer expires. Timers set in the past will fire "soon".

Because the current time may wrap around, it is possible to use values of t0 greater than the getNow's result. These values represent times in the past, i.e., the time at which getNow() would last of returned that value. @param t0 Base time for timer. @param dt Time until the timer fires.

documentation.short: Set a single-short timer to some time units in the future.
documentation.long: Set a single-short timer to some time units in the future. Replaces any current timer settings. Equivalent to startOneShotAt(getNow(), dt). The fired will be signaled when the timer expires. @param dt Time until the timer fires.

documentation.short: Cancel a timer.
documentation.long: Cancel a timer.

documentation.short: The Notify interface is intended for delivery of values from self-triggered devices, at relatively low rates.
documentation.long:
The Notify interface is intended for delivery of values from self-triggered devices, at relatively low rates. For example, a driver for a motion detector or a switch might provide this interface. The type of the value is given as a template argument. Generally, these values are backed by memory or computation. Because no error code is included, both calls must be guaranteed to succeed. This interface should be used when a single logical unit supports both getting and setting.

See TEP114 - SIDs: Source and Sink Independent Drivers for details. @param val_t the type of the object that will be stored @author Gilman Tolle @version $Revision: 1.4 $ $Date: 2006-12-12 18:23:14 $

documentation.short: Disables delivery of notifications from the device to the calling generic client component.
Enables delivery of notifications from the device to the calling generic client component.
Signals the arrival of a new value from the device.
documentation.long:
Signals the arrival of a new value from the device.
@param val the value arriving from the device

documentation.short: Similar to the <tt>Set</tt> interface (see TEP 114) this interface can be used for storing small values, but in contrast to the <tt>Set</tt> interface the value is stored asynchronously.
documentation.long:
Similar to the <tt>Set</tt> interface (see TEP 114) this interface can be used for storing small values, but in contrast to the <tt>Set</tt> interface the value is stored asynchronously.
@param data_type the type of the object that will be stored

documentation.short: Stores a value of type <tt>data_type</tt>.
An Alarm is a low-level interface intended for precise timing.
documentation.long:
An Alarm is a low-level interface intended for precise timing.

An Alarm is parameterised by its "precision" (milliseconds, microseconds, etc), identified by a type. This prevents, e.g., unintentionally mixing components expecting milliseconds with those expecting microseconds as those interfaces have a different type.

An Alarm's second parameter is its "width", i.e., the number of bits used to represent time values. Width is indicated by including the appropriate size integer type as an Alarm parameter.

See TEP102 for more details. @param precision_tag A type indicating the precision of this Alarm. @param size_type An integer type representing time values for this Alarm. @author Cory Sharp

documentation.short: Return the current time.
documentation.long: Return the current time. @return Current time.

documentation.short: Signaled when the alarm expires.
documentation.long: Signaled when the alarm expires.

documentation.short: Set a single-short alarm to time t0+dt.
documentation.long:
Set a single-short alarm to time t0+dt. Replaces any current alarm time. The fired will be signaled when the alarm expires. Alarms set in the past will fire "soon".

Because the current time may wrap around, it is possible to use values of t0 greater than the getNow's result. These values represent times in the past, i.e., the time at which getNow() would last of returned that value. @param t0 Base time for alarm. @param dt Alarm time as offset from t0.

documentation.short: Check if alarm is running.
documentation.long: Check if alarm is running. Note that a FALSE return does not indicate that the fired event will not be signaled (it may have already started executing, but not reached your code yet). @return TRUE if the alarm is still running.

documentation.short: Return the time the currently running alarm will fire or the time that the previously running alarm was set to fire.
Set a single-short alarm to some time units in the future.
documentation.long: Set a single-short alarm to some time units in the future. Replaces any current alarm time. Equivalent to start(getNow(), dt). The fired will be signaled when the alarm expires. @param dt Time until the alarm fires.

documentation.short: Cancel an alarm.
documentation.long: Cancel an alarm. Note that the fired event may have already been signaled (even if your code has not yet started executing).
